You should be able to explain this formula. This generalizes – if I have

You should be able to explain this formula.

First consider a set of discrete outcomes
= i
⁢ 1 … N
, each with probability
P i
(like a weighted six sided die). The sum of probabilities is unity

Associated with each outcome is a quantity
x i
, e.g.
x 3
the money you get for rolling a three. Then the mean of
x
(the mean money you get by rolling the die)

For a given quantity
x
we define the deviation from the average

and the average deviation is zero
=
⟨
⁢ δ x
⟩
0
. Then the variance is the mean of the squared deviation
The standard deviation is

For continuous variable we need the concept of a probability distribution. The probability,
⁢ d P
, to find a particle with position in a range between
x
and
+ x
⁢ d x
, which we denote
[ x ,
+ x
⁢ d x
]
, is denoted

Math.text: d * P = P * x * d * x

para.p:
where the probability density
⁢ P
( x )
is
A very important probability density is the Gaussian or “normal” distribution which you should try to memorize:

Math.text: P * x = (1 / square-root@(2 * pi * sigma ^ 2)) * e ^ (- (x ^ 2 / 2) * sigma ^ 2)

para.p: It is also called the Bell shaped curve and you should be able to sketch it. In class and in homework we showed:
And worked out a number of integrals

Math.text: delimited-⟨⟩@(x ^ n) = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(P * x * x ^ n * differential-d@(x)) = sigma ^ n * C _ n
delimited-⟨⟩@(x ^ n) = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(P * x * x ^ n * differential-d@(x)) = sigma ^ n * C _ n

Consider a two dimensional probability distribution

Math.text: d * P _ (list@(x, y)) = P * open-interval@(x, y) * d * x * d * y

para.p:
This is the probability of
x
in

The constants can be arranged so that
⁢ P
( x )

( y )

Math.text: formulae@(integral@(P * x * differential-d@(x)) = list@(1, [and]), integral@(P * y * differential-d@(y)) = 1)

para.p: When the distributions are independent

For definiteness, consider a sequence of random steps in position
x
. Assume
x 1
, the step in position from step number one, is drawn from the probability distribution
⁢ P
( x )
. Also assume second step
x 2
is drawn from the same distribution, and that the choice of
x 2
is no way dependent on
x 1
. Similarly, the third step
x 3
is drawn from
⁢ P
( x )
and is no way dependent on
x 1
or
x 2
; and so on for
x 4
,
x 5
,
⁢
x 6
…
. Then we want to know what is the mean, variance, and probability distribution of the sum

Math.text: Y = x _ 1 + x _ 2 + ldots + x _ N

para.p: The answer is for the mean and variance are

In general the probability of
Y
depends on
⁢ P
( x )
, and nothing much can be said about
⁢ P
( Y )
. However, if
N
is large
≫ N 1
, then, remarkably, the probability of
Y
takes on a universal form of a Normal distribution

Math.text: P * Y = (1 / square-root@(2 * pi * (sigma _ Y) ^ 2)) * exponential@(- ((Y - delimited-⟨⟩@(Y)) ^ 2 / 2) * (sigma _ Y) ^ 2)

section.title: 1.2Estimates of ideal gasses and the equipartition theorem

para.p: The pressure of an ideal gas satisfies

Math.text: p * V = n _ ml * R * T

para.p:
Here
n ml
is the number of moles, while
≡ n
/ N V
is reserved for the number of particles per volume. The number of moles is the number of particles in units of Avogadro’s number,
≡
n ml
/ N
N A
, so we define Boltzmann’s constant
k B

Math.text: formulae@(p * V = N * k * T, k _ B equivalent-to R / N _ A)

para.p:
Sometimes we will drop the “B” and just write
⁢ k T
for
⁢
k B
T
.
Numerically

Math.text: formulae@(R = (8.32 * J) / ^ compose K, k _ B = ((1 / 40) * e * V) / (300 * ^ compose K))

para.p:
The reason for writing
k B
like this is because this is how people (including me) remember it: e.g. typical thermal energy,
∼
⁢
k B
T
, is “one fortieth of electron volt at room temperature”,
≃ T
⁢ 300
K ∘
.

The typical value of pressure is
⁢ 1 bar
=
/
⁢
10 5
N
m 2
≃
⁢ 1 atm
, a typical volume is a liter,
⁢ 1 L
=
(
⁢ 10 c m
)
3
=
⁢ 1000
cm 3
=
⁢
10
- 3
m 3
. We note

Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP) is one bar at
⁢ 273
K ∘
(freezing). The volume of one mole of gas at STP is 22 L.

The equi-partition theorem states that mean energy per “degree of freedom (dof)” in the gas is
⁢
1 2
k T
. We will explain what we mean here by dof using examples. Take a mono-atomic gas. Each an atom which can move in three ways – in the
x
, the
y
, and the
z
directions. Thus the number of dof is
⁢ 3 N
where
N
is the number of atoms in the gas. So the total mean total energy in the energy in the gas, which we call
U
or
E
(they are the same in our notation), is

Math.text: U equivalent-to E = (3 / 2) * N * k * T

para.p:
The energy (or Hamiltonian) of each particle, which we typically call
ϵ
, is a sum of three quadratic forms

Technically, the equipartition theorem says that the mean energy of each independent subsystem (i.e. a single particle) is
⁢
1 2
k B
T
per quadratic form in the classical Hamiltonian – there are three forms counting the
v x
2
,
v y
2
and
v z
2
terms. Each quadratic form gives
⁢
1 2
k B
T
so
and
The root means square velocity is

Math.text: v _ rms = square-root@(delimited-⟨⟩@((vec@(v)) ^ 2)) = square-root@((3 * k _ B * T) / m)

para.p:
and is typically a couple of hundred meters a second, i.e. close to the speed of sound
≃
c s
/
⁢ 330 m
s
.

For a classical diatomic gas there are five degrees of freedom (quadratic forms) per molecule, since the diatomic molecule can also rotate around the
x
and
y
axis. One must include the translational and rotational kinetic energy

We note that instead of working with the velocity and angular velocity we will increasingly work with the momentum
=
p x
⁢ m
v x
and the angular momentum
=
L x
⁢ I
ω x
,

The average of each of these five quadratic forms is
⁢
1 2
k B
T
so the mean energy per particle is

A system has total energy
U
. If a subsystem within the sytem has energy
ϵ
, the rest of the system has energy
- U ϵ
. The subsystem should be small and independent of the rest of the system (except in regard to energy exchange), eg. a molecule in an ideal gas. Probability the subsystem will have energy
ϵ
is proprtional to
e
-
⁢
/ ϵ
k B
T

Math.text: P * epsilon proportional-to e ^ (- (epsilon / k _ B) * T)

para.p:
This is the Boltzmann factor. We can simplify
= β
⁢
k B
T
such as to not have to write so much. If you have a set of microscopically small states
= i

=
⁢ P
( ϵ )
⁢ C
e

we have

C

/ 1 Z

Math.text: formulae@(C = list@(1 / Z, [with]), Z equivalent-to (sum _ i)@(e ^ (- beta * epsilon _ i)))

para.p:
Z
is known as the partition function and is important in what follows. Then the probability of finding the subsystem in state
r
with energy
ϵ r
is the following

Math.text: P * epsilon = e ^ (- (epsilon / k _ B) * T) / Z

para.p:
Avogadro’s number
=
N A
× 6
10 23
.

The speed of light
= c
/
⁢
× 3
10 8
m
s

The speed of sound in air is approximately
≃
c s
/
⁢ 330 m
s
.

A useful unit of volume is liters. One liter is
=
(
⁢ 10 cm

3

cm 3
. One mole of an ideal gas at STP has a volume of
⁢ 22 L

A useful unit of pressure is a bar. One atmosphere is approximately 1 bar. 1 bar is
/

N
m 2

The ideal gas constant is

/

K ∘

The Boltzmann constant
k B
you can remember in two ways:

The macroscopic way: one Avogadro’s number times
k B
is
R
:

The microscopic way:
⁢ k T
is “one fortieth of an eV at room temperature”,
= T
⁢ 300
K ∘
.
You should remember the proton (and neutron mass) in two ways:
The microscopic way: i.e. the rest energy in mega electron volts is

Math.text: m _ p * c ^ 2 similar-to-or-equals 938 * MeV similar-to-or-equals 1000 * MeV similar-to-or-equals 1 * GeV

para.p: The macroscopic way: an Avagadro’s number of protons weighs a gram. This is the molar mass of the proton:

Math.text: M _ ml = m _ p * N _ A = 1 * g

para.p:
Protons and neutrons and weigh nearly the same thus the mass of one Avagadro’s number of diatomic oxygen weighs
⁢ 32 g
, since there are eight protons and neutrons in one oxygen nucleus, and two such nuclei. The electrons are light (see below) for the mass budget.

You might want to use either of these methods to evaluate
v rms
in atomic hydrogen gas at room temperature

Math.text: v _ rms = square-root@((3 * k * T) / m _ p) = c * square-root@((3 * k * T) / (m _ p * c ^ 2)) = ((3 * 10 ^ 8 * m) / s) * square-root@(((1 / 40) * eV) / (938 * 10 ^ 6 * eV)) similar-to-or-equals (2700 * m) / s

para.p: Or if you prefer

Math.text: v _ rms = square-root@((3 * k _ B * T) / m) = square-root@((3 * N _ A * k _ B * T) / (N _ A * m _ p)) = square-root@((3 * R * T) / (1 * g)) = square-root@((((3 * 8.32 * J) / ^ compose K) * 300 * ^ compose K) / (1 * g)) similar-to-or-equals (2700 * m) / s

para.p:
This is almost a factor of 10 faster than the speed of sound
≃
c s
/
⁢ 330 m
s
, because hydrogen is so light.
You should remember the electron mass in two ways:
The microscopic way: the mass is “half an MeV”
In comparison to the proton mass:
Plancks constant is needed to convert wavelength to energy

or using
= h
⁢ 2 π ℏ

Thus the energy of a photon of yellow light with
= λ
⁢ 550 nm
(emitted by sodium) is

Math.text: E = (h * c) / lambda = (1240 * eV * nm) / (550 * nm) similar-to-or-equals 2.3 * eV

para.p: Planks constant is also useful for measuring typical de Broglie wavelength at room temperature

Math.text: h / square-root@(m _ p * k * T) = (h * c) / square-root@(m _ p * c ^ 2 * k * T) similar-to-or-equals (1240 * eVnm) / square-root@(10 ^ 9 * eV * (1 / 40) * eV) similar-to-or-equals 2.5 * ring@(A)

para.p:
A useful unit of distance in atomic physics is angstroms,
=
⁢ 1
̊ A
⁢ 0.1 nm
. The Bohr radius

is about half an Angstrom. A typical bond length is normally between 1-5 Bohr Radii. (For
N 2
the distance between the two nuclei is
⁢ 1.09
̊ A
)

An electron volt is a good unit of microscopic energy. Avagadro’s number times
⁢ 1 eV
is a good unit of macroscopic chemical energy and is 100 kilo Joules.

This is sometimes called the Faraday constant 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 We can quickly find the charge in Coulombs from this relation,
(A.16) Equation A.16 A.16
⁢ 1 e V
≃
/
⁢ 100 kJ
N A
≃
⁢

- 19
J

and so
⁢ 1 e

10
- 19
C
.
. An explosion involves roughly an Avogadro’s number of atomic transitions, with each atomic transition releasing about an electron volt of energy, for approximately
⁢ 100 kJ
of energy per mole. Burning a mole of gasoline gives roughly this amount of energy.
The Bohr model provides a lot of estimates of the microscopic world.

In the Bohr model the radius of the lowest electron orbit is
=
a 0
⁢ 0.53
̊ A
, and the angular momentum of the lowest orbit is discrete,
L =

a 0
= ℏ
. So the momentum is

reflecting the uncertainty principle. In the lowest orbit Bohr orbit the kinetic energy is half of the potential energy in magnitude 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 This follows from Newton’s Law for a circular orbit for an electron attracted to the proton via the Coulomb force:
=
⁢ m
v 2
r
e 2

r 2
. The potential energy is negative reflecting the positive charge
+ e
of the proton and negative charge
- e
of the electron. The potential energy of the orbiting electron is
The binding energy of the electron to the proton

is the Rydberg constant. For the ground states of a quantum mechanical system it is often the case that

para.p: Suppose, for example, the integral integral you are trying to compute is an integral over position:

Math.text: I = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(differential-d@(x) * x ^ 4 * e ^ (- x ^ 2 / ell ^ 2))

where
ℓ
has units of length. Then
∝ I
ℓ 5

ℓ 5

x

/ x ℓ
(the position in units of

absent = ell ^ 5 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(differential-d@(u) * u ^ 4 * exponential@(- u ^ 2))

We discussed the integrals

Math.text: I _ n = (1 / square-root@(2 * pi)) * ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(differential-d@(x) * e ^ (- x ^ 2 / 2) * x ^ n)

para.p: The first couple results are
We found these using the generating function technique.
The gamma function is a useful special function that extends the domain of the factorial function to non-integer values. It is defined by the integral

Math.text: Gamma * n = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(x ^ (n - 1) * e ^ (- x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: and has the familiar recursive relationship

starting from
=
⁢ Γ
( 1 )
1
. We have

While the gamma function is defined for all complex numbers except the non-positive integers, analytical expressions are only known where
n
is an integer or half-integer. In particular,

So for instance
=
⁢ Γ
(
/ 3 2
)
/
π
2
.

In statistical mechanics, the gamma function occurs frequently in integrals involving the Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution. In addition, the area of a sphere in
d
dimensions is
which comes up a lot later in the course
